clinical_study.brief_title: InTSHA: Interactive Transition Support for HIV-infected Adolescents Using Social Media
clinical_study.official_title: InTSHA: Interactive Transition Support for HIV-infected Adolescents Using Social Media

brief_summary.textblock: Determine the acceptability and feasibility of a social media intervention among adolescents living with HIV who are transitioning to adult care in South Africa.

detailed_description.textblock: The PI will perform a pilot randomized controlled trial with 40 adolescents receiving the social media intervention and 40 adolescents receiving standard of care. The PI will use in-depth interviews and quantitative surveys with adolescents living with HIV and to assess the acceptability and feasibility of the intervention as primary outcomes. The PI will also assess the secondary outcomes of peer support, connection to clinical staff, retention in care, and viral suppression at baseline and 6 months after randomization.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: A pilot randomized controlled trial with 40 adolescents receiving a social media intervention and 40 adolescents receiving standard of care.

primary_outcome.description: Quantitative assessment of acceptability based on the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT).

secondary_outcome.description: Using the Child and Adolescent Social Support Scale. Total sale reported ranging 0 to 200 with higher number representing higher social support
Using the Working Alliance Inventory. Measures connection to clinical staff. Total scale reported 12 to 84. Higher number represents more connection to clinical staff.
Using the Rosenberg scale. Total reported ranging 0 to 30. Higher number is more self-esteem
Using the TRANSITION Q scale. Total reported with scale 0 to 42. Higher number is more ready for transition.
Number of clinic visits and pharmacy refills in the last 6 months
We will report the total number of individuals who complete the InTSHA intervention out of the n=40 that are randomized to the intervention group.
Using the HIV Adolescent Readiness for Transition Scale (HARTS). Total reported. Range 0 to 51. Higher score is more ready to transition.

arm_group.description: 40 adolescents receiving the social media intervention

intervention.description: Determine the acceptability and feasibility of the social media intervention among adolescents living with HIV who are transitioning to adult care in South Africa

patient_data.ipd_description: Deidentified individual participant data will be available on request and will include demographic data, age, sex, baseline CD4, viral load, results of baseline and end of study questionnaires on transition readiness, self-esteem, social support, connection to clinic and end points of acceptability, feasibility, retention in care and viral suppression.
